name: LambdaDeployFunction
description: General purpose deployment of AWS Lambda functions for all supported language runtimes.
author: Amazon Web Services
helpMarkDown:
Please refer to [AWS Lambda Developer Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/) for more information on working with AWS Lambda.

More information on this task can be found in the [task reference](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vsts/latest/userguide/lambda-deploy.html).

####Task Permissions
This task requires permissions to call the following AWS service APIs (depending on selected task options, not all APIs may be used):
* lambda:CreateFunction
* lambda:GetFunction
* lambda:GetFunctionConfiguration
* lambda:UpdateFunctionCode
* lambda:UpdateFunctionConfiguration

inputs.name: awsCredentials
inputs.label: AWS Credentials
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the AWS credentials to be used by the task in the build agent environment.

You can specify credentials using a service endpoint (of type _AWS_) in the task configuration or you can leave unspecified. If unspecified the task will attempt to obtain credentials from the following sources in order:

* From task variables named _AWS.AccessKeyID_, _AWS.SecretAccessKey_ and optionally _AWS.SessionToken_.
* From credentials set in environment variables in the build agent process. When using environment variables in the build agent process you may use the standard AWS environment variables: _AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_, _AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_ and optionally _AWS_SESSION_TOKEN_.
* If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from the instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance. For credentials to be available from EC2 instance metadata the instance must have been started with an instance profile referencing a role granting permissions to the task to make calls to AWS on your behalf. See [Using an IAM Role to Grant Permissions to Applications Running on Amazon EC2 Instances](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-ec2.html) for more information.

inputs.name: regionName
inputs.label: AWS Region
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The AWS region code (us-east-1, us-west-2 etc) of the region containing the AWS resource(s) the task will use or create. For more information see [AWS Regions and Endpoints](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html).

If a region is not explicitly configured the task will attempt to obtain the region to be used from the following sources:

* From a task variable named _AWS.Region_.
* From the standard AWS environment variable _AWS_REGION_ in the build agent's environment.
*  If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance.

__Note:__ The regions listed in the picker are those known at the time this software was released. New regions that are not listed may still be used by entering the _region code_ of the region (for example _us_west_2_).

inputs.name: deploymentMode
inputs.label: Deployment Mode
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selects the type of deployment. You can deploy new function code to an existing function or you can specify settings for both code and configuration. For the 'code and configuration' mode if the function does not exist it will be created.

options.codeandconfiguration: Update code and configuration (or create a new function)

inputs.name: functionName
inputs.label: Function Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Lambda function to create or update. You can also specify the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for an existing function.

inputs.name: description
inputs.label: Description
inputs.helpMarkDown: A short, user-defined function description. Lambda does not use this value.

inputs.name: functionHandler
inputs.label: Function Handler
inputs.helpMarkDown: The function within your code that Lambda calls to begin execution. For Node.js, it is the module-name.export value in your function. For Java, it can be package.class-name::handler or package.class-name. For more information and other examples see [Programming Model](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/programming-model-v2.html).

inputs.name: runtime
inputs.label: Runtime
inputs.helpMarkDown: The runtime environment for the Lambda function you are uploading. The list of runtimes available in the pick list are those known at the time this version of the tools was released. To use a runtime not shown in the list simply enter the runtime identifier in the field.

inputs.name: codeLocation
inputs.label: Code Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: The source of the code for the function. You can select a zip file in the work area or a zip file previously uploaded to Amazon S3. If the source location is Amazon S3 you can also optionally supply a specific version of the file.

options.localfile: Zip file in the work area

inputs.name: localZipFile
inputs.label: Zip File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the zip file containing the function code to deploy. Required if _Code Location_ is set to _Zip file in the work area_.

inputs.name: s3Bucket
inputs.label: S3 Bucket Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Amazon S3 bucket containing the previously uploaded zip file of the function's code. Required if _Code Location_ is set to _Zip file in Amazon S3_.

inputs.name: s3ObjectKey
inputs.label: S3 Object Key
inputs.helpMarkDown: The key (name) of the object in the bucket containing the function's code.  Required if _Code Location_ is set to _Zip file in Amazon S3_.

inputs.name: s3ObjectVersion
inputs.label: S3 Object Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Version of the S3 object containing the function code. If not specified the latest version of the object is used.

inputs.name: roleARN
inputs.label: Role ARN or Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN), or name, of the IAM role that Lambda assumes when it executes your function to access any other Amazon Web Services (AWS) resources. If a role name is supplied the task will attempt to retrieve the ARN automatically.

inputs.name: memorySize
inputs.label: Memory Size
inputs.helpMarkDown: The amount of memory, in MB, your Lambda function is given. Lambda uses this memory size to infer the amount of CPU and memory allocated to your function. Your function use-case determines your CPU and memory requirements. For example, a database operation might need less memory compared to an image processing function. The default value is 128 MB. The value must be a multiple of 64 MB.

inputs.name: timeout
inputs.label: Timeout
inputs.helpMarkDown: The function execution time at which Lambda should terminate the function. Because the execution time has cost implications, we recommend you set this value based on your expected execution time. The default is 3 seconds.

inputs.name: publish
inputs.label: Publish
inputs.helpMarkDown: If set requests AWS Lambda to create or update the Lambda function and publish a version as an atomic operation.

inputs.name: layers
inputs.label: Lambda Layers
inputs.helpMarkDown: List of Lambda Layer ARNs (including version), one per line.

inputs.name: deadLetterARN
inputs.label: Dead Letter ARN
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an Amazon SQS queue or Amazon SNS topic to be used as your Dead Letter Queue (DLQ).

inputs.name: kmsKeyARN
inputs.label: KMS Key ARN
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key used to encrypt your function's environment variables. If not provided, AWS Lambda will use a default service key.

inputs.name: environment
inputs.label: Environment Variables
inputs.helpMarkDown: Key-value pairs that represent your environment's configuration settings. Enter as Name=Value, one per line.

inputs.name: tags
inputs.label: Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: List of tags (key-value pairs) assigned to the new function. Enter as Key=Value, one per line. Tags can only be specified when creating a new function and are ignored when updating functions.

inputs.name: securityGroups
inputs.label: Security Group IDs
inputs.helpMarkDown: List of security group IDs, one per line. If your Lambda function accesses resources in a VPC at least one security group and one subnet ID must be specified, which must belong to the same VPC.

inputs.name: subnets
inputs.label: Subnet IDs
inputs.helpMarkDown: List of subnet IDs, one per line. If your Lambda function accesses resources in a VPC at least one security group and one subnet ID must be specified, which must belong to the same VPC.

inputs.name: tracingConfig
inputs.label: Tracing Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Trace settings for your function.

options.Active: Respect any tracing header received from an upstream service
options.PassThrough: Only trace the request from an upstream service if it contains a tracing header with 'sampled=1'

inputs.name: outputVariable
inputs.label: Output Variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the variable that will contain the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the created or updated function on task completion. The variable can be used as $(variableName) to refer to the function result in subsequent tasks.

inputs.name: logRequest
inputs.label: Log Request
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, request headers and other data for calls to AWS services are logged to the task's debug log.

inputs.name: logResponse
inputs.label: Log Response
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the response metadata and body content of non-streaming responses from calls to AWS services are output to the task's debug log. The unique request ID, which can be useful when contacting AWS for support, is always logged to the task output regardless of this option setting.

messages.FunctionNotFound: Function %s does not exist, cannot update code only
messages.TaskCompleted: Completed create or update of Lambda function %s, function ARN %s
messages.NoFunctionArnReturned: No function ARN returned from the service! Deployment failed!
messages.SettingOutputVariable: Setting output variable %s with the function output
messages.AwaitingStatus: Waiting for function %s to reach %s state...
messages.CantWaitWarning: Role doesn't have Lambda States waiting permissions; will wait %s seconds and proceed. To avoid this in the future, grant %s permissions to the task role!
